reviews.review_msg: Gordon's lectures start off ok but are overshadowed by her ego and unsupported opinions with no credited sources just her beliefs. Final exam was a jokeâ€”attending class felt unnecessary. Group projects presentations disorganized, she made groups change topics just two days before presenting due to her NOT LIKING certain topics. Avoid at all cost!
Assignments are hard, but lecture are entertaining and the curve is very generous.

Avoid/drop! Do whatever you need to do to not be in her class. Uploaded slides are not the same she shows in class. She is condescending to anything she doesn't agree with. Unfair to students. Unclear deadlines and criteria. Final exam is a joke as in u could skip ALL semester n still write the final np. She nit-picks DSM and theories

I am truly shocked at the amount of 1 star reviews for Iris. She's unorganized, isn't clear on the grading criteria, and only gives vague responses to questions, but her entertaining lectures and humour made me enjoy the course more. She gets a big ehh from me, but I certainly wouldn't say she's the absolute worst prof I've had.
Class felt so dragged on and never ending. Lectures were always so long and multiple assignments.

great prof but I felt like this class consumed so much of my time. No exams in the course but spends way too much time doing the lecture which is pointless and has so many class activities going on, its a little much. On top of that, there's a weekly worksheet & 3 paper & podcast assignment. Must attend class as well.

I wish that I had more credits left in my degree to continue taking courses with Dr. Aknin - I'm not sure I've had a more compassionate professor at SFU. I use the word 'compassionate' because it truly reflects in Dr. Aknin's teaching style, interactions with students, and course material. I cannot possibly offer high enough praise for her.

Lara is the most compassionate prof I have ever had. If you ever have a personal issue, she is very accommodating. Her lecture material is fascinating and applicable to the real world. Grading is precise, and assignments are given well in advance. I wish she taught more UG courses, I would take them all. I highly recommend it!

A very fun class about happiness. Dr. Aknin is very passionate about the topic and it shows in the way she presents the material. No exams to study for which was nice. Very flexible grading as she gave us the choice of dropping 1 of 3 assignments. Weekly reading assignments and some individual and group projects were pretty self-explanatory.
Pretty cool course. The content is interesting and it's not a difficult class.

Do not recommend this class - so unorganized with impossible exams that are difficult to study for. The TA laura is an actual goddess (wow) and the star is for her because she took the time to help me understand the material and learn how to score better on the exams. Avoid this class but if you must take it use the TA for help
Grace is a lovely lady, but her class and lectures are super unorganized. It seemed like the class was not prepared properly in advance as the lectures and tests didn't match up well.

Selected studies - developmental disabilities. Class and lectures were not organized well. Too much time spent on anecdotal stories from students. No real prep for mid term or cumulative final. Says to focus on bigger picture but tests on specifics.
Horribly organized,  doesn't test on what she teaches, doesn't clarify and expects a wealth of knowledge on a specific subject that she does not teach.
Whoever rating her high, are you seriously kidding me? No.
I took a course with her. I didnt like her. Material is dry and class is boring.

if you are interested in clinical psyc, this is definitely the class to go for. Jennifer explained the materials clearly tho she sometimes just read off the ppt slides. Assignments were fair, 3 assignments, 2 quizzes, 1 final. Final was long- multiple choices, short questions (few pages) and a short essay, but i thought it's manageable. Recommended

If you want to go for clinical psychology, take this course! Everyone complains about the amount of material you have to read, but it's not difficult to grasp. Show up/study/stay on top of it and you'll do great. Quizzes are short and cover lecture material. It's really not too hard. If you're mad a 4th yr course isn't easy, that's your problem.

Intro to Clinical Psyc had so much potential but was so poorly done. This is the most amount of reading I have had to do in a course ever... plus it was boring. There is an extreme amount of content, and she expect you to know everything in precise detail. Save yourself and pass on taking this class. Not worth the amount of work.

Overall not a bad class or teacher, but the material is almost always incredibly dry. Jen's teaching style is pretty rigid and dry also, but you can tell she's passionate about clinical psychology. It's a helpful class if you're looking in to becoming a clinical psychologist, although painfully dry

Took this course some years ago. Like many students, I felt entirely let down by the lecturer. The lecture was all over the place. I am very surprised by the sudden shift in ratings (from very negative to very positive).

I enjoyed taking psyc 391 with prof. Anjum. She is really knowledgeable about so many cultures and the course content. I enjoyed her course very much because of how to clearly she teaches. In addition to regular classes she holds many office hours. She is definitely one of the best profs at SFU.

She is a very knowledgeable and caring professor. For the environmental sustainability course, she provided an easy assignment for 3 extra percentage assignment so that students can boost their grades. Since the contents can get heavy, she made the exams open book. The TAs also mark fairly.
Professor Anjum is a wonderful professor. Regardless of being a tough grader she has certain charm in her classes and her office hours.

She is a great professor and only she can talk about so many cultures, places, and people. The papers she shares were great but I am not a fan of the book that was used in this course. Next time she should teach only papers and no books.
A professor full of ideas and inspiration.

Gulnaz is a great addition to psychology professors. I love her classes and I am taking another course now. It is great to see how she changes her tempo depending upon the nature of course. In Psy366 she is an impressive activist and yet a cool professor. I am a minority student and I love that she talks about diverse issues. Much respect for her.

She is a great professor. Her lecture is very interesting. She engages with students throughout her lectures and outside lectures. She makes the content of her lectures easy to understand. Her exams are fair for those of us who attend classes and study. I like that!

Loved this course but there was one downside, we had too much homework for this course. She gave us weekly assignments which was a lot of additional work. She was kind and respectful. She spent way more time in classes than other profs at SFU.
For a cross-cultural psychology, we needed a person who has knowledge of diverse cultures. Liked her non-traditional approach in the classroom.
Hardworking and Caring. Cares a lot about students' learning and wellbeing.
Absolutely amazing teacher.
She is the best Professor ever. Extremely caring and professional in her teaching approach.

Gulnaz is all over the place, is specific on fine detail that is irrelevant and there's lots of outside of lecture components that don't back up what she says. She might know the material but doesn't know how to teach. Test questions (MC) are worded dumb and SA she is looking for very specific things from lecture/slides. Won't be taking her again

As mentioned, there is room for improvement. Also not equally accessible to all students outside of class time. Tends to only respond back to very few, selected emails. Gives unclear instructions for assignments and overall not engaging. Definitely hard to focus when every other word is "um you know"

Professor Anjum is very caring and accommodates her students' choices. She provided more than enough time for both midterm and final so that students can comfortably participate. As she is a new professor, there are room for improvements, such as the lecture can be more engaging. If you follow her lectures, you will do well in the class.

I used to think professors were highly intelligent and well educated, but after taking a class with Gulnaz, I realize that is not true. If you choose to take a class with her after reading all these reviews, maybe you deserve her.
I just want to talk to the person who gave her the job because wow she's terrible.

Sweet but disorganized. Changed the grading scheme that was outlined on the syllabus AFTER marking final exams without announcing it to the class and refused to take any questions/offer feedback on the final exam. Lecture content was contradictory to the textbook and MC was either from lecture or textbook content; you never know which she wants.

The lectures are long and dry. Material on the slides are sentences straight from the textbook. Lecture doesn't always match what is presented on the slides. Assigns a lot of extra material on top of weekly textbook readings. Assignment criteria is confusing. Pay special attention to profs published work - it will show up on tests.

This professor just reads you the textbook, which is not acceptable imo for an upper div psychology class. There is not anything particularly interesting about the way she teaches, it is super dry and boring.

Troy was AMAZING in Indigenous Peoples and Psych. I didn't really think i'd enjoy the class too much, but I was completely locked in every lecture bc he teaches with passion and clearly has expertise. We had two papers and one final exam, so the course didn't feel that work heavy. Lectures were 3hrs and you are required to attend lectures! :)

You can tell that Troy is very passionate about his course. He is super compassionate and generous with students about extensions and omitting participation marks. Assignments are weighted heavily and writing intensive with 55% of the final grade being papers. HIs lectures feel very long, boring and he tends to mumble a bit.

Troy is a great professor, he is passionate about what he teaches and truly cares about his students. With open communication, he will help you and give extensions when needed. He is awesome, but he is a very tough grader. And the weight of the assignments are very high. Final is worth 35%, paper 1 25%, and paper 2 30% alongside the midterm.

I had Troy for the Indigenous Peoples section of 391 and I cannot recommend him enough. The content covered in this class is heavy so the lectures can be tough to get through but his knowledge more than makes up for this. He's explicit with assignment rubrics as well so you're told exactly how to succeed in the class. All around a great guy.

What a great professor! I had him the previous semester and wanted to take a course with him again just because I was familiar with his marking/ grading. Take a course with him, you won't be disappointed

Great class + the content was interesting! Though the exams were difficult, I was able to get a B! The assignment looks scary (worth 40%) but it was fun & can easily boost your grade! I did mine in 1 day and got 88% & class average was 77%! She gives examples in class for the paper as well! Highly recommend if you want to learn about IPV/stalking!

Sarah was super nice. Amidst the covid-19 pandemic, she was accommodating and communicated frequently. She is definitely a tough grader and expects a lot for her exams. Other than that, I really enjoyed her class: shes a greater lecturer and brought her own research into the course.

I loved this class! I learned a tremendous amount and now have a much better understanding of IPV and stalking. Sarah expected a lot from students, but readings were provided through canvas and lectures were recorded.

Schmitt is a wonderful professor. He is knowledgeable and passionate, and he really cares about his students. He goes above and beyond when you ask him for help. Make sure the writing assignments are well written, as there are plenty of guidelines to help you... 100% would take again.

Tests are fair, all questions are based on lecture and article reading. Also considering the fact that all tests are MC questions based, it is a relatively easy credit for upper level Psyc course. Be carefully with TA's marking on the term paper term though, could be a big time killer.
Exams are hard although they are MC questions. We got peer review to edit the paper which is pretty helpful.

He's a great prof. 100% would take again. He had high interest in the subject and knows how to lecture and catch attention. Knows how to speak with pauses and not get you bored. Also doesn't overload slides or lectures with useless info. He's awesome. Tests are fair too. Good assignments. Readings interesting and no textbook. Just articles.

Michael is great. He's passionate about the environment. its great that he's teaching a class in it bc when profs are passionate about the subject, it really makes the class that much more interesting and even inspiring. The project is fun and definitely taught some things about myself. One of the most useful classes, I've taken in uni!

Very fun and interesting class! He is very passionate about it and it shows in lectures. Lectures were short and fun, easy to grasp material. Read all articles because they form the basis of the exams! Overall easy class and fun project that motivates you to do something for the environment

Very boring class. nothing really about psychology. He replies emails SO slow and very impatient. Not a helpful teacher. but the class is not difficult. Just simply boring for a psyc class. All exams are MC. Learned nothing useful from this course. regrets!

Dr. Schmitt is passionate about environmental & social psychology, & he didn't only make a difference in my academic life, but in my life in general. He adds components of experiential education in his teachings, which make it easier for students to relate to concepts. He is engaging, funny, & draws upon material which are meaningful & interesting.

One of the easiest classes I've taken so far! He's very helped, he put my files into pdf form when I was having trouble uploading files. 2 mts and 1 term paper and 3 mini papers. All super easy, there should be no reason for not getting a good grade. I got an A- in the course. Make sure to do the readings for the mts.

good class. interesting topics. HARD EXAMS!! 3 exams for intersession, aka every 2 weeks. really difficult, but the iclicker questions for attendance were easy & not marked anyway, plus the final paper is based on a movie. fun class but make sure to study the articles & their findings

Boring class, the notes were confusing and all over the place, and Kim was confusing as a prof. She contradicts herself a lot and wastes class time trying to figure out how to work her i-clicker and powerpoint. This class was boring and you'll leave lectures being even more confused than when you walked in.
Lectures are super interesting and she is very approachable! Really enjoyed her class!

I took Jennifer's History of Madness class and I have to say it has been one of my favourite Psyc classes throughout my entire degree! She is very enthusiastic, approachable and wants her students to do well. I highly recommend this course as the material is very interesting and midterm/final and paper are straightforward :)

I had Jennifer for History of Madness Spring 2013. This is a new course she has developed for SFU. It's a fascinating course, I highly recommend it. She is good instructor, really organized and engaging in lectures. She taught the material in a way that was interesting and well-organized. Assignments, midterm were fair.
Easy A. Shes a great prof, just attend lectures and you will do well. She gives you 3 chances to do each quiz which makes it really easy to achieve high grades

I cannot say more good things about Dr. Girme!! She is by far the most caring and understanding prof I have ever had. I go out of my way to take any and every class she teaches every semester! She is fair, approachable, kind, respectful of your time and opinions and is very knowledgeable about her courses! If you get the chance, take her classes!

Yuthika is my favorite professor at SFU! Her lectures were REALLY interesting and really well explained. The final exam was really fair and not too hard at all. I really want to take another class with her again!
I mean this is the prof that you want to always study with. Enroll in her courses, you learn a lot and get good grades.
Best psychology prof ever met, caring for students and the mastery grading is a masterpiece. Study well and it would be an A.

AMAZING! Nicest, kindest, professor I ever had. Her classes are engaging and tied to relevant events in society. She is very quick to reply to emails and is very nice to chat with. Her grading is fair and she is more concerned with teaching you than curving the class to the typical B average. In her class, everyone has a chance for an A.

Hands down best prof I've ever had. She makes a podcast for the course content every week that makes learning the material fun. She gives you three attempts at quizzes to master them, which makes up 60% of your grade. Her teaching style really sets you up to succeed as the class average was in the A range.
Her lecture is very interesting and makes the content easy to understand !!
Hands down best professor at SFU. she genuinely cares about your progress and success in the class. Also HILARIOUS.

Dr. Grime is one of the best profs I have ever had. Her lectures are fun and enjoyable and the content presented is very clear. Her lecture 'quizzes' are all opinion-based, and you only have to go to 10 lectures to receive full credit. Must do the readings as it will be on the midterm/final exam. Overall, an amazing prof.

Yuthika is an amazing professor! Her class is actually really interesting if you're especially interested in social psychology and relationships! I'm hoping in the future she will teach more classes because I would take another class with her.

Yuthika herself is a great lecturer and we learned useful life-changing information but damn was this class hard. Short answers were impossible because you have to memorize the diagrams WORD FOR WORD. Paper was vague and graded harshly. 60% Average for midterm and class was not scaled up.

Rachel is a wonderful prof. However, her teaching of the course was based on the textbook and it doesn't seem like she knew what she was teaching besides follow what the book author wrote. The grading breakdown of the class was unclear. 2 quizzes, 1 test, 1 paper, some in class activities! She buys us timbits after a quiz so thats a plus!

I found the lectures and material to be interesting. He's a really nice prof if you go to office hours and is always willing to explain in further detail. Test material comes straight out of the text book if you read it. You pretty much get what you put in. Material is engaging in itself.

Unfortunately I have to agree with those who posted before me about the quizzes having extremely confusing, often even structurally incorrect wording. If you've already taken 250, 280, or 371 this will be a hard class 4 u as it takes a step back. Things u're tested on don't seem to make much sense. It's great material presented in a very poor way.

Studied my brains out for this class and the exams/quizzes were just too confusingly worded with double negatives and spelling errors that it didn't even matter how much I actually knew. He reads right off the slides which are pretty much word for word from the textbook. Assignments/tests were confusing and unclear and he was hard to understand.

Brianna is really nice. Her midterm and final are hard. You'll have to memorize quite a bit but she's very helpful if you have questions. The assignments are pretty straight forward and can definitely be grade booster.  Overall, interesting topic and Brianna knows the topic pretty well.
Clearly passionate about the material, an interesting speaker, and the hottest male prof I've had yet - and not just because he's the only one under 50.

Shona is one of the nicest professors out there. She wants everyone to do well and gives everyone the opportunity to do so. The class is curved but if you keep up with the lecture objectives, do the weekly quizzes and go to her office hours for help with the assignment early on you will do great. The lectures can sometimes be dry but interesting!

Your ATTITUDE determines your ALTITUDE. Not with Shonas class unfortunately. The class curved and was too easy, scaling very high. You can go after participation marks and study test banks for word for word exam. Shona is passionate about the material but someone else needs to structure it so a 70% wont be a D. Working smart > attitude.

Possibly the worst professor I've encountered at SFU. The slides are just like the textbook and all she does is read the slides Felt like high school. She made the course too easy and didn't have a midterm so the class average was high, so people with 70 failed the class. She then sent a super insulting email telling us we should have worked harder

Shona seems sweet but not a good prof. Lectured about material that wouldn't be on the final. Always an issue with marks not being calculated properly for assignments and exams. She submitted the final grades, then 2 days later had to change everyone's because she didnt calculate properly. Very annoying!!

Avoid, seems easy but class is curved and average is high. 70% and below is a D lmao. 40% participation/open-book quizzes, 30% paper, 30% final. Only the learning objectives/weekly quizzes on the final. Lots to cover, lectures are boring and she covered material not on the final. Only attended for participation and left. Would not recommend :(

Shona is passionate about the work, she's not ready to teach yet. No midterm, easy class overall (untimed test bank quizzes, heavy participation marks, etc). Course curved. Class average was so high a 69 would get you a D. Shona's system assisted with this problem. Lecture lacked relative info, time spent on slides that "won't show up on the exam".

Easy course, not a good teacher. Very very disorganized. Boring lectures. Very condescending tone toward students. Lectures often went over time for no reason, making it difficult to get to other classes. Seems like a nice person but not at all an effective teacher. Useless textbook, lectures repeated textbook content directly (boring). Avoid.

Literally show up and pass. Boring lectures, not enough content. Learn human resources and googling about clinical psychology. Only studied the quizzes and got an A. Dropped over $100 for a textbook I didn't read. Class avg was really high. You had to get 100% on the essay and final and quizzes or you will get a B+ or lower. LOL

First of all, she does not just read off the slides and the lectures are not boring. Listening to lecture on the other hand is not necessary per say, but she gives LOTS of hints for tests if you do pay attention which will save you a lot of time in the long run. The weekly quizzes are much better than a midterm, but a CUMULATIVE exam kinda sucks.

Very straightforward and interesting class. 13 quizzes, one paper, and a final exam. Final exam consisted of exactly the same questions from the take-home quizzes. 30 multiple choice questions and 6 short answers. Powerpoint slides are very detailed and useful although they sometimes too detailed. Don't hesitate to take this class, prof is amazing.

A very nice new professor from Great Britain! I love her accent. She is very passionate about the subject. The course is very well articulated. The only thing is final exam is cumulative which worth 40% of your mark. There are tons of things to memorize so make sure you study and work hard. Powerpoint slides are very informative and useful.

Very nice professor, clearly passionate about the material and very knowledgable and approachable. Lectures were a little disorganized in terms of chapter progression and identifying which slides were for which chapters. But overall solid class.

Shona is absolutely great. You can tell she really truly cares for the students and wants us to succeed. Plus, her examples and anecdotes from her work as a clinical psychologist help to clarify the material and make it much more engaging. Overall she gives off really positive vibes which make the lecture environment very welcoming.
Great prof and participation was worth 20% of the grade. So just show up and use your iclicker to get a decent mark in the class

One of the best classes I have taken at SFU. Lecture material/slides are detailed, she also made sure lectures were recorded, and gave us everything we would need to be successful in the course. She explained everything well, and gives her students opportunities to get good grades. Grading is through participation and online quizzes, no midterm.

I'd definitely take another class with Shona. She has interesting stories from her experience as a clinical psychologist, and is very approachable and friendly. Not sure on marking yet as I'm still in the course, but lots of easy marks for participating in class. This is her first time teaching but I think she's doing a great job :)

Took psyc 391 with him in Spring 2020. He is an amazing prof. So caring, so considerate. Went out of the way to make sure all his students scored good in times of pandemic. Very flexible and responsive

This was my second class with Dr. Gervais and he was amazing in both. He is one of the most compassionate and approachable professors there is. He handled COVID-19 with boundless concern for student well-being, significantly more than any other professor I had. I have learnt so much in his courses and he makes success possible as long as you try!

Class involved mundane lectures and 3 tests. 30% included participation marks where anyone could get full credit, leading to a curve of anything below 70% resulting in a D. Despite mediocre efforts, he sent out an email congratulating himself for handling the covid situation. Take this prof for a subpar experience that will likely lower your gpa.

Despite the whole COVID-19 pandemic, Dr. Gervais was amazing. He kept in contact with everybody, checking in and keeping us updated, he also adapted to the situation smoothly and gave leniency due to the conditions. He was quick to grade everything and give feedback. Too bad its his last semester at SFU, I wouldve taken another class with him!

Professor Gervais ratings have nothing to do with the difficulty of the course, only people who are upset about a poor grading scheme. However, he has since corrected it and now a 90 will be within the A range (the norm for psyc upper divisions). He is very passionate about the material and is very accessible for help! Ignore the bad reviews!!!

Hey, I wanted to make a clear distinction between Dr. Gervais' PSYC 391 courses - there is a culture course and a newer emotion course - please remember to make it known which one you took, it isn't fair to rip him when his culture course has gotten rave reviews and it seems his emotion course has been less than ideal. I took Culture!

Do not take Mathew, was a horrible instructor. He was so disorganized, seemed to barely understand the material and read from a script. In the end he had to curve everyone down to the point where a 90 was a B.

He is the worst professor I have ever had at SFU. The reviews below are all true he will talk down to you. I do not recommend this class AT ALL. He cant even teach his lecture in order his lecture is all over the place with majority of the slides consisting of pictures only. Skip this class at all costs unless someone else is teaching it!

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. He CURVES STUDENTS DOWN. The in-class assignments are easy as they include group work and are sometimes opinion-based questions. Midterms are fair but you must memorize every study in the textbook. If you get a mark in the 70s youre getting a C-. Skip taking this class.
Dont take this class. Awful grading scheme. He Curves students down. Textbook is a must!
Hes so incredibly disorganized and is constantly changing the grading scheme. Overall would not take again.
For all those out there who did not like 391 or Matt, dont worry he isnt even truly a Psyc instructor, he couldnt get that far so he stuck to Anthropology. He is meaningless
Hes a nice prof but he doesnt curve so a 74% is a C- in his grading scheme. Overall hes a little disorganized but exams are fair. You must have the textbook and memorize all the studies listed.
Gervais is a nice prof, although his tests are extremely content heavy. The exams can trip you up, and his lecture slides at times are disorganized and don't always go in order.

Really great class! Gervais is a fun teacher and discussed a lot of interesting topics. Obviously a 3hr lecture can be long and tiring but he managed to keep the energy up and engage the class in the content. I would definitely take another class with him as the teacher! Exams were easy as long as you studied and showed up for classes.

Prob the easiest 300 lvl course. Total of 20 in class activities, lowest 3 are dropped. At least 60% were opinion based, others u can find in the textbook. ALL 3 midterms are 40 MCQ. wording is a little confusing to trip u up tho. Lectures are a little heavy (3 hrs), but he's good looking so it makes up for it. 10/10 would recommend this course!!!
his class is interesting, he is nice. 30 percent in-class activity and the activities are pretty easy. just the class is curved

Matthew is a new and nice prof at SFU, I like him very much due to his light work and interesting topic. The 34% in-class writing is very very easy, just like a gift LOL And his midterms are quite easy as well. Highly recommend this course!!!!

Matthew is eager new prof at SFU. Attendance is mandatory as there are 2 in-class assignments per lecture totaling of 34% of your final grade. He drops the 3 lowest assignments. There were 3 exams, 22% each. Class is lecture heavy, sometimes he asks for specific details in readings so make sure to take notes and especially pay attention to studies.
Great prof. Straight forward format for his Cultural Psych class. 3 exams and easy attendance activities in class.

The 34 % in-class activities are quite easy. You just answer 4 quesions each class. But make sure dont be late bc sometimes his activities r at the beginning of the lecture. Despite the easy activities, he has never shown us a marking scheme until the final exam is done. I have 76% and always thought its a b+. He curved and I got c+.

Attendance is mandatory since there are two short activities which weigh total 34%. Activities were short reading responses which were fairly easy if you've done the readings. Reading the textbook is a must as exams are straight out of the textbook. You can easily pass this course with decent grade if you read the textbook.

She's great. She responds to emails really quickly, is very understanding, fair, and professional. She really cares about the subject she teaches and really puts extra effort into making sure that student are engaged. This class is really worth it. Just make sure to do your reading before class.

Sarah is possibly the best professor I have ever had. She is very kind, approachable and always has a big smile on her face! The course content is very interesting and she adds to it by sharing personal anecdotes from her practice. I would take a random class just to have a lecture with her again!
